{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Securities Commission |nativename_r = |logo = Seccom-nz-logo.gif |logo_width = |logo_caption = |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |formed = 1978 |preceding1 = |dissolved = 30 April 2011 |superseding = [[Financial Markets Authority (New Zealand)|Financial Markets Authority]] |jurisdiction = |headquarters = [[Wellington]], [[New Zealand]] |employees = 51<ref>[http://www.sec-com.govt.nz/publications/annrep-09/08.shtml#EAC 2009 Annual Report - Recruiting and retaining staff ]</ref> |budget = |minister1_name = |minister1_pfo = |minister2_name = |minister2_pfo = |chief1_name = Jane Diplock |chief1_position = Chairman (2001 - 2011) |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |parent_agency = |child1_agency = |keydocument1 =[http://www.justaccounting.co.nz/AR2009.pdf] |keydocument2 =[http://www.justaccounting.co.nz/AR2008.pdf] |website =http://www.sec-com.govt.nz/ |footnotes =The Financial Markets Authority no longer officially recognizes this predecessor organisation. }} The '''Securities Commission''' was an independent [[Crown entity]] of the government of [[New Zealand]] and the main regulator of investments. It was replaced on 1 May 2011 by the [[Financial Markets Authority (New Zealand)|Financial Markets Authority]].
It was responsible for enforcement, monitoring and market oversight of the securities markets, authorising participants and promoting public understanding of investments. This included authorising the [[New Zealand Stock Exchange]] with which it ran a co-regulatory model.
On 27 April 2010 the New Zealand minister for commerce [[Simon Power]] announced that Securities Commission would be replaced by a new integrated financial regulator the Financial Markets Authority.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=10641503 |title=One financial regulator to rule them all |publisher=NZ Herald |date=29 Apr 2010 |first=Adam |last=Bennett}}</ref>
==History== The Commission was first established under the Securities Act 1978 which determines its powers and functions.
The commissions role was modified and extended by a number of additional pieces of legislation. These include the Securities Markets Act 1988, the Investment Advisers (Disclosure) Act 1996, the Securities Regulations 1983, the Securities Act (Contributory Mortgage) Regulations 1988, and the Securities (Fees) Regulations 1998.
The Financial Advisers Act 2008 gave the Securities Commission new responsibilities to register and set minimum standards for financial advisers. There was some concern that the commission did not have the resources to effectively carry out its responsibilities<ref>[http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/BU0909/S00664.htm Securities Commission needs staff, money and IT]</ref> and that this additional responsibility would make the situation worse.
The agency was chaired by Jane Diplock from 2001 until it was disbanded in 2011 and faced criticism for its handling of the collapse of a large number of finance companies.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.goodreturns.co.nz/article/976495596/diplock-defends-commission-over-fin-coy-failures.html |publisher=Good Returns |title=Diplock defends commission over fin coy failures |date=September 9, 2009 }}</ref> Jane Diplock was also the chairperson of the [[International Organization of Securities Commissions]] (IOSCO) during her time as chairperson of the Securities Commission.
==Responsibilities and functions== The Securities Commission undertook the following roles: * Enforcement, monitoring and market oversight * Law reform * Exemptions * Authorisations * International co-operation and * Promoting public understanding
==Notable cases== * In May 1993 the Commission published a very extensive report on the manipulation of reported profits by the largely Government owned Bank of New Zealand. "Arrangements" to make the manipulation look valid were put in place in March 1988 but in the event they were not used until the Banks 1990 year when the Bank's profit was overstated by $55m.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.justaccounting.co.nz/reca.pdf |title= Report of an Enquiry into Certain Arrangements entered into by Bank of New Zealand in March 1988 |date=24 May 1993 |publisher=New Zealand Securities Commission}}</ref> * In June 2007, [[Michael Fay (banker)|Michael Fay]] and [[David Richwhite]] through one of the companies that they co-owned, Midavia Rail Investments, paid $20 million to the commission to settle [[insider trading]] proceedings relating to [[Tranz Rail]]. In October 2004 the commission accused Midavia of insider trading and Richwhite of tipping off Midavia to sell $63 million worth of shares while knowing Tranz Rail was facing financial problems, which was not known to the public. The commission noted that the payments had been made "without any admission of liability".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/2360561/Fay-Richwhite-money-a-hard-sell |title=Fay Richwhite money a hard sell |date=24 April 2009 |publisher=Fairfax NZ News }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=3600217 |title=Former Tranz Rail shareholders face insider trading charges |publisher=The New Zealand Herald |date=June 5, 2011 }}</ref>
*On 11 November 2007 the NZ Securities Commission issued a report<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.justaccounting.co.nz/seccomfeltex2.html|title=Feltex Carpets Ltd IPO Prospectus Financial Reporting and Continuous Disclosure|last=|first=|date=11 November 2007|website=Justaccounting|publisher=NZ Securities Commission|access-date=}}</ref> into two matters concerning Feltex Carpets Ltd which by then had gone into liquidation with the probable loss of all shareholders funds. The first matter was an Initial Public Offer<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.justaccounting.co.nz/feltexpros.pdf|title=Feltex Carpets Prospectus|last=|first=|date=April 2004|website=|publisher=Feltex Carpets Ltd|access-date=29 April 2016}}</ref> made in April 2004 by which a sole shareholder sold all its shares to the public for about $250m. The report declared that this IPO was not misleading in any material particular. Nevertheless over three thousand of the eight thousand subscribers to this IPO have taken legal action against various parties associated with making the offering on the grounds that the offering was misleading. The High Court (Houghton v Saunders)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.chapmantripp.com/publications/Documents/Houghton%20v%20Saunders.pdf|title=Houghton v Saunders|last=|first=|date=|website=Chapman Tripp|publisher=High Court|access-date=}}</ref> found against the shareholders and as at April 2016 the matter is being considered by the Court of Appeal.
:In the second matter the Securities Commission reported that Feltex had overstated the length of tenure of most of its extensive bank debt in its half yearly report to 31 December 2005. The Ministry of Economic Development took legal action against five of the Feltex directors as a result of this Securities Commission report but in MED v Feeney Judge M Doogue dismissed the charges.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.chapmantripp.com/publications/Documents/2011%20PUB%20BC%20Directors%20backsides%20exposed%20if%20noses%20in%20fingers%20out.pdf|title=Directors Backsides Exposed|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Chapman Tripp|access-date=29 April 2016}}</ref> Judge Doogue specialized in family court matters. Less than a year after this judgement she was promoted to Chief District Court Judge.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.courtsofnz.govt.nz/district/district/the-judges/judge-chief|title=Chief District Court Judge|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Justice Department|access-date=}}</ref>
* On 20 June 2010, the Securities Commission put the [[Financial institution|finance company]] ''South Canterbury Finance'' which was run by [[Allan Hubbard (businessman)|Allan Hubbard]] into statutory management after complaints from a number of investors.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.beehive.govt.nz/release/aorangi-securities-charitable-trusts-and-hubbards-placed-statutory-management |title=Aorangi Securities, charitable trusts, and Hubbards placed into statutory management |first=Simon |last=Power |publisher=New Zealand Government |date=20 June 2010 |accessdate=11 April 2012}}</ref> This also triggered an investigation by the [[Serious Fraud Office (New Zealand)]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/serious-fraud-office/news/article.cfm?o_id=371&objectid=10653246 |title=SFO to investigate Hubbards |newspaper=The New Zealand Herald |author=BusinessDesk |date=20 June 2010 |accessdate=21 October 2010 }}</ref> Eight weeks later on the 31 August 2010, South Canterbury Finance was placed in receivership.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.nbr.co.nz/article/some-big-winners-south-canterbury-collapse-129218 |title=Some big winners from South Canterbury collapse |work=The National Business Review |first=Chris |last=Hutching |date=31 August 2010 |accessdate=11 April 2012}}</ref>
* In late 2010, the Securities Commission successfully applied to the [[High Court of New Zealand|High Court]] to have the assets of former director of [[Financial institution|finance company]] [[Hanover Finance]], [[Mark Hotchin]] frozen.<ref name="frozen">{{cite news | author = NZPA | issn = 1170-0777 | title = Hotchin assets frozen by High Court | work = New Zealand Herald | accessdate = 21 December 2010 | date = 15 December 2010 | url = http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=10694484 }}</ref>

{{Refimprove|date=September 2014}} In American law, a '''signing agent''' or '''courtesy signer''' is an agent whose function is to obtain a formal signature of an appearer to a document. In common parlance, most jurisdictions require the appearer to sign before a [[notary public]]. From this, the practice of a notary public designating themselves as a signing agent has arisen. There are notaries public who specialize in the notarization of [[real estate]] transfer and loan document signings. Signing agents often have certification and training through private organizations, but is not a requirement in law, although it may be a requirement of the lender in the oversight of real estate transaction document signatures.
Also referred to as a ''notary signing agent'' or a ''loan signing agent'', a signing agent should not be confused with a [[mortgage loan closer|mortgage loan closer or closing agent]]. Signing agents are notaries public, who usually have experience and/or training concerning the proper execution of loan documents and are hired by mortgage companies, escrow companies, title companies, and signing services to identify loan documents, obtain the necessary signatures, and in some cases deliver the documents to the borrower. A signing agent is an impartial party to the transaction, and must adhere to the notary laws of their state or jurisdiction. In some states of the United States where signing agents are allowed, signing agents may identify documents and can point out terms to the loan transaction. However, signing agents are prohibited from giving legal advice or in any way explaining or interpreting the meaning of any terms or documents, and they are not permitted to prepare the documents, or alter them in any way. Any advice, explanation, or opinion can be considered unauthorized practice of law, except in the State of Louisiana, which is governed by Civil Law; in Louisiana, civil law notaries public have broad powers, and can actually prepare documents and discuss them with the signers.
The American Signing Agents Association Inc defines the signing agent as, "A signing agent is a trusted professional, usually a state commissioned notary public, that performs the closing ceremony for real estate transactions, mortgage loan transactions, legal process transactions and other similar transactions where an independent third part is requested. A signing agent should insure that they are disinterested in the transaction and have a mutual obligation to all parties to remain objective, neutral to any position, insure awareness of document contents by affiant and make a reasonable effort to prevent fraud and protect affiants from coercion."<ref>[http://www.americansigningagents.org/home/standards/what-is-a-signing-agent American Signing Agents Association Inc: ''What is a Signing Agent'', 2012] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130410084313/http://www.americansigningagents.org/home/standards/what-is-a-signing-agent |date=2013-04-10 }}</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2014}}
'''TV Everywhere''' (also known as '''authenticated streaming''' or '''authenticated video on-demand''')<ref name="verge-starzplay">{{cite web | url=https://www.theverge.com/2012/10/8/3473290/starz-play-encore-play-cox-streaming-video | title=Starz Play and Encore Play 'authenticated' streaming video now available for Cox customers | publisher=Vox Media | work=The Verge | date=October 8, 2012 | accessdate=January 2, 2014 | author=Ingraham, Nathan}}</ref> refers to a [[business model]] wherein access to [[streaming video]] content from a television channel requires users to "authenticate" themselves as current subscribers to the channel, via an [[user account|account]] provided by their participating [[pay television]] provider, in order to access the content.
Under the model, broadcasters offer their customers the ability to access content from their channels through [[Internet television|internet-based]] services and [[mobile app]]s—either live or [[Video on demand|on-demand]], as part of their subscription to the service. [[Time Warner Cable]] first proposed the concept in 2009; in 2010, many television providers and networks began to roll out TV Everywhere services for their subscribers, including major networks such as [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]] and [[TNT (U.S. TV network)|TNT]] (whose owner was an early supporter of the concept), [[ESPN]], and [[HBO]] among others. Broadcast television networks have also adopted TV Everywhere restrictions for their online content.
Television providers and broadcasters have touted the advantages of being able to access content across multiple platforms, including on the internet, and on [[mobile device]]s (such as [[smartphone]]s and [[tablet computer|tablets]]) as part of their existing television subscription. The TV Everywhere concept has received criticism for being difficult for end-users to set up, while media activists have criticized the concept for being a [[paywall]] that extends the existing [[oligarchy]] of the subscription television industry to the internet, and considering it to be [[collusion]] against [[cord cutter]]s—those who drop cable and satellite entirely in favor of accessing content via terrestrial television, the internet, and subscription [[video on demand]] (SVOD) services.
== Rationale == TV Everywhere services were developed in an attempt to compete with the [[market trend]] of [[cord cutting]], where consumers drop traditional pay television subscriptions in favor of accessing TV content exclusively through over-the-air television and/or online on-demand services, including [[Hulu]], [[Netflix]], [[YouTube]], and other sources. Authenticated streaming and video on-demand services allow traditional television providers to directly compete with these competitors, and add value to existing television subscriptions in an effort to retain subscribers.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/23/business/media/23couch.html?_r=1&ref=sofa_wars | title=In the Living Room, Hooked on Pay TV | work=The New York Times | date=August 23, 2010 | accessdate=January 2, 2014 | author=Matt, Richtel | author2=Stelter, Brian}} {{subscription needed|date=August 2014}}</ref><ref name=mcn-critical/>
In particular, broadcasters and providers have emphasized the use of TV Everywhere services to allow [[multi-platform]] access to their content, on devices such as personal computers, [[smartphone]]s, [[tablet computer|tablets]], [[digital media player]]s, and [[video game console]]s.<ref name="mcn-critical">{{cite web | url=http://www.multichannel.com/content/how-critical-tv-everywhere | title=How Critical Is TV Everywhere? | publisher=NewBay Media | work=Multichannel News | date=October 17, 2011 | accessdate=January 2, 2014 | author=Spangler, Todd}}</ref>
== History ==
=== Precursors === [[ESPN Inc.|ESPN]] first introduced a TV Everywhere-like concept with [[ESPN360]], a service which allowed users to stream [[Broadcasting of sports events|sports programming]] from its networks either live or on-demand through a website. However, access to ESPN360 was restricted to the users of [[internet service provider]]s who had negotiated deals with ESPN to offer the service; a model closer in nature to cable television carriage. Similar tactics were soon used by several other channels, such as [[NFL Network]] (who used the technique to restrict access to its ''Game Extra'' service for ''[[Thursday Night Football]]'') and [[Epix (TV network)|Epix]]. David Preschlack, ESPN's executive vice president for affiliate sales and marketing, foresaw a future in the model, believing that access to exclusive content would soon play a greater role in competition between high-speed internet providers. However, the model was deemed a violation of the principles of [[net neutrality]] by some critics.<ref name="wired-espntoisps">{{cite web | url=https://www.wired.com/2009/02/espn-stands-fir/ | title=ESPN to ISPs: Pay for Your Customers to Play Video | publisher=Condé Nast | work=Wired | date=February 5, 2009 | accessdate=January 2, 2014 | author=Buskirk, Eliot Van}}</ref><ref name=ars-tvforeveryone/><ref name="wired-360neutrality">{{cite web | url=https://www.wired.com/business/2009/06/cable-isps-see-net-neutrality-foul-in-espn-online-video-charges/ | title=Cable ISPs See Net Neutrality Foul in ESPN Online-Video Charges | publisher=Condé Nast | work=Wired | date=June 12, 2009 | accessdate=January 5, 2014 | author=Singel, Ryan}}</ref>
=== Introduction and adoption === In 2009, [[Time Warner Cable]] announced an initiative known as ''TV Everywhere'', a set of principles which were "designed to serve as a framework to facilitate deployment of online television content in a way that is consumer friendly, pro-competitive."<ref name="ars-comcastexpand"/> The concept would enable users of their respective cable television services to access live and on-demand online content from channels that they subscribe to by using an account-based authentication system. TWC CEO [[Jeffrey Bewkes]] believed that the TV Everywhere principles were "good concepts" that are "likely to be the general direction for all TV networks and all the distribution connections that are out there."<ref name="ars-tvforeveryone"/> That summer, both TWC and [[Comcast]] began trials of services based on the system; [[Turner Broadcasting]] was an early supporter of the system, providing access to [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]] and [[TNT (U.S. TV network)|TNT]] content as part of the trials. Comcast officially launched a public beta of its TV Everywhere-based portal, Xfinity Fancast, in December 2009 for all double-play television and internet customers. Afterwards, other providers began to follow suit.<ref name=mcn-critical/><ref name="ars-tvforeveryone">{{cite web | url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2009/06/is-comcast-and-timewarners-tv-everywhere-tv-for-everyone/| title=Is Comcast and Time Warner's "TV Everywhere" TV for everyone? | publisher=Condé Nast | work=Ars Technica | date=June 24, 2009 | accessdate=January 2, 2014 | author=Lasar, Matthew}}</ref><ref name="ars-comcastexpand">{{cite web | url=https://arstechnica.com/business/2009/12/comcast-expands-online-video-to-all-cableinternet-customers/ | title=Comcast expands online video to all cable+Internet customers | publisher=Condé Nast | work=Ars Technica | date=December 15, 2009 | accessdate=January 2, 2014 | author=Cheng, Jacqui}}</ref>
In 2010, broadcasters and television providers began a wider roll-out of TV Everywhere-based services; for the [[2010 Winter Olympics]], [[NBC Sports]] offered live and video on-demand access to events throughout the Games that required users to authenticate for access.<ref name="sbj-testcase">{{cite web | url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2009/04/20090413/This-Weeks-News/Olympics-A-Test-Case-For-Web-Video.aspx | title=Olympics a test case for Web video? | publisher=Advance Publications | work=Sports Business Journal | date=April 13, 2009 | accessdate=January 2, 2014 | author=Ourand, John}}</ref> Also in February, [[HBO]] launched HBO Go, a video on demand service exclusive to HBO subscribers on participating providers.<ref name="engadget-hbogo">{{cite web | url=https://www.engadget.com/topics/hd/2010/02/17/eyes-on-with-hbo-go/ | title=Eyes-on with HBO GO | publisher=AOL Inc. | work=Engadget | date=February 17, 2010 | accessdate=January 2, 2014 | author=Drawbaugh, Ben}}</ref> In September 2010, [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]] would begin launching an array of TV Everywhere-based services, including [[WatchESPN]] (a successor to ESPN360 offered to ESPN television subscribers), and similar apps for [[Disney Channel]] and [[Disney XD]].<ref name="mcn-modelforfuture">{{cite web | url=http://multichannel.com/news/policy/comcast-disney-deal-model-future/264273 | title=Comcast-Disney Deal a Model for Future | publisher=NewBay Media | work=Multichannel News | date=January 9, 2012 | accessdate=January 2, 2014 | author=Reynolds, Mike}}</ref>
In August 2011, [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] became the first over-the-air network to restrict on-demand access with a TV Everywhere-based system; "next day" on-demand episodes (either through its website or [[Hulu]], itself a joint venture between Fox, [[NBC]], and [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] at the time) would only be available online to users authenticating themselves as a subscriber to a cable or satellite provider, or those who subscribe to the Hulu Plus service. All other users would be subject to an 8-day delay.<ref name="nyt-foxhulu">{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/27/business/media/fox-to-limit-next-day-streaming-on-hulu.html | title=Fox to Limit Next-Day Streaming on Hulu to Paying Cable Customers | work=The New York Times | date=July 26, 2011 | accessdate=January 2, 2014 | author=Stelter, Brian}} {{subscription required|date=August 2014}}</ref> On September 1, 2011, fellow Fox property [[Big Ten Network]] (a [[college sports]] network dedicated to the [[Big Ten Conference]], operated in partnership with [[Fox Sports (United States)|Fox Sports]]) also launched a TV Everywhere service known as ''BTN2Go''.<ref name="btn2go-mcn">{{cite web | url=http://multichannel.com/news/cable-operators/btn2go-kicks-four-distributors/327365 | title=BTN2GO Kicks off with Four Distributors | publisher=NewBay Media | work=Multichannel News | date=September 1, 2011 | accessdate=January 2, 2014 | author=Renyolds, Mike}}</ref>
=== Expansion === Matt Strauss, Comcast senior vice president of digital and emerging platforms, considered the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] to be a "watershed" event for TV Everywhere services; [[NBCUniversal]] announced that a total of nearly 10 million authenticated devices accessed its online coverage during the Games across both the NBCOlympics.com site and NBC Olympics Live Extra app; in particular, parent company Comcast accounted for 3.3 million devices from 1.5 million users.<ref name="mcn-watershed">{{cite web | url=http://multichannel.com/news/cable-operators/comcasts-strauss-2012-olympics-were-tv-everywhere-watershed-event/326328 | title=Comcast's Strauss: 2012 Olympics Were 'TV Everywhere' Watershed Event | publisher=NewBay Media | work=Multichannel News | date=August 14, 2012 | accessdate=January 2, 2014 | author=Spangler, Todd}}</ref> Following the Games, the service was rebranded as NBC Sports Live Extra to serve as a general streaming app for the [[NBC Sports]] division.<ref name="engadget-nbcliveextra">{{cite web | url=https://www.engadget.com/2012/09/01/nbc-rebrands-olympics-app-as-nbc-sports-live-extra-promises-str/ | title=NBC rebrands Olympics app as NBC Sports Live Extra, promises streams for a wider athletic universe | publisher=AOL Inc. | work=Engadget | date=September 1, 2009 | accessdate=April 19, 2014 | author=Fingas, Jon}}</ref>
TV Everywhere services also began to appear in Canada in the early 2010s, with the Canadian launch of [[HBO Canada|HBO Go]] in 2012,<ref name="thr-hbogocanada">{{cite web | url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/hbo-go-mobile-app-headed-274232 | title=HBO Go Mobile App Headed to Canada | publisher=Prometheus Global Media | work=The Hollywood Reporter | date=December 15, 2011 | accessdate=January 2, 2014 | author=Vlessing, Etan}}</ref> and the 2013 announcement of TV Everywhere services from [[Bell Media]] (beginning with [[Bravo (Canada)|Bravo Go]], and also including [[CTV Television|CTV Go]]) and [[Shaw Media]] (beginning with [[Global Television Network|Global]]). The majority of Canadian broadcasters are [[vertical integration|vertically integrated]]; both Bell and Shaw operate [[internet service provider]]s and national satellite television services.<ref name="torstar-globalgo">{{cite web | url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/television/2013/09/11/shaw_media_launches_global_go_for_global_tv_shows.html | title=Shaw Media launches Global Go for Global TV shows | work=Toronto Star | date=September 11, 2013 | accessdate=January 2, 2014 | author=Wong, Tony}}</ref><ref name="globe-bravogo">{{cite web | url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/bell-media-to-give-subscribers-full-online-access-to-bravo/article12377681/ | title=Bell Media to give subscribers full online access to Bravo | work=The Globe and Mail | date=June 6, 2013 | accessdate=June 6, 2013 | author=Ladurantaye, Steve}}</ref><ref name="tsn-tsngo">{{cite web | url=https://www.tsn.ca/other_sports/story/?id=446002 | title=TSN GO brings live streaming of the biggest events in sports | publisher=Bell Media | work=TSN | date=March 12, 2014 | accessdate=May 6, 2014 | author=TSN.ca staff}}</ref>
In May 2013, ABC released its Watch ABC [[mobile app]], which allows viewers on participating providers to access live streams from participating ABC affiliates.<ref name="variety-watchabc">{{cite web | url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/news/abc-to-stream-live-via-app-1200479778/ | title=ABC to Stream Live Via App | publisher=Penske Media Corporation | work=Variety | date=May 12, 2013 | accessdate=June 1, 2013 | author=Wallenstein, Andrew}}</ref><ref name="engadget-watchabc">{{cite web | url=https://www.engadget.com/2013/05/31/watch-abc-app-kindle-fire/ | title=Watch ABC app with live TV streaming comes to Kindle Fire, but not Google Play | publisher=AOL Inc. | work=Engadget | date=May 31, 2013 | accessdate=June 1, 2013 | author=Lawler, Richard}}</ref> In December 2013, ABC confirmed that it would impose a similar restriction to Fox for "next day" on-demand episodes beginning on January 6, 2014, with 7-day exclusivity for authenticated users and Hulu Plus subscribers.<ref name="variety-abclimit">{{cite web | url=https://variety.com/2013/digital/news/abc-to-limit-new-episodes-online-to-paying-subscribers-starting-jan-6-1201015862/ | title=ABC to Limit New Episodes Online to Paying Subs for One Week | publisher=Penske Media Corporation | work=Variety | date=December 31, 2013 | accessdate=January 2, 2014 | author=Spangler, Todd}}</ref> NBC unveiled its own plans for a similar TV Everywhere app to its affiliate board in April 2014.<ref name="nbc-tveaffiliates">{{cite web | url=http://broadcastingcable.com/news/local-tv/nab-nbc-unveils-tv-everywhere-app-affiliates/130344 | title=NAB: NBC Unveils TV Everywhere App for Affiliates | publisher=NewBay Media | work=Broadcasting & Cable | date=April 7, 2014 | accessdate=May 25, 2014 | author=Malone, Michael}}</ref>
In November 2015, after negotiations surrounding [[revenue sharing]] and infrastructural mandates (including a proposed requirement that the games only be available through the league's existing apps), [[Major League Baseball]] reached a three-year deal with Fox to allow it to offer in-market online streaming on Fox Sports Go (though streamed using [[MLB Advanced Media]] infrastructure) for the 16 teams that it holds regional rights to through the [[Fox Sports|Fox Sports Networks]] division.<ref name=sbj-foxinmarket>{{cite web|title=MLB, Fox break impasse in streaming talks|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2015/08/17/Media/MLB-streaming.aspx|website=Sports Business Journal|accessdate=17 August 2015}}</ref><ref name=mcn-inmarket>{{cite web|title=MLB, RSNs Yet To Bridge In-Market Streaming Differences|url=http://www.multichannel.com/mlb-rsns-yet-bridge-market-streaming-differences/389010|website=Multichannel News|accessdate=17 August 2015}}</ref><ref name=sbj-mlbinmarket>{{cite web|title=MLB, Fox Sports Agree To Three-Year Deal For In-Market Game Streaming, Beginning In '16|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Daily/Issues/2015/11/20/Media/MLB-Streaming.aspx|website=Sports Business Journal|accessdate=13 January 2016}}</ref> In December 2015, [[Discovery Communications]], a long hold-out on the concept, launched Discovery Go, a centralized TV Everywhere service and mobile app for [[Discovery Channel]], [[TLC (TV channel)|TLC]], as well as its array of sister networks.<ref name=mcn-discoverygo>{{cite web|title=Discovery Bows TV Everywhere App|url=http://www.multichannel.com/news/content/discovery-bows-tv-everywhere-app/395629|website=Multichannel News|accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref>
== Reception == The TV Everywhere concept has been met with mixed reception. Some broadcasters were initially hesitant to introduce TV Everywhere services, with concerns that they might affect advertising revenue and not be adequately counted by [[Nielsen ratings]].<ref name=mcn-critical/> [[Songwriters Guild of America]] president Rick Carnes praised the TV Everywhere concept and other recent developments for helping to provide easier, legal access to premium content online.<ref name="ars-plottokill">{{cite web | url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2010/01/tv-everywhere-causing-controversy-everywhere/ | title=TV Everywhere: gift to consumers or plot to kill online TV? | publisher=Condé Nast | work=Ars Technica | date=January 6, 2010 | accessdate=January 2, 2014 | author=Lasar, Matthew}}</ref>
Media activists have criticized the concept as protecting the existing [[closed platform|closed]], regionalized [[oligarchy]] of multichannel television by tying digital content to traditional television subscriptions, thus harming fully [[over-the-top content|over-the-top]] competitors. [[Public Knowledge]] believed that "under the 'TV Everywhere' plan, no other program distributors would be able to emerge, and no consumers will be able to 'cut the cord' because they find what they want online. As a result, consumers will be the losers."<ref name=ars-tvforeveryone/> A 2010 report by [[Free Press (organization)|Free Press]] made similar arguments, contending that TV Everywhere was an act of [[collusion]] by the cable industry, and arguing that "by tying programming to local cable subscriptions, while denying content to pure online TV distributors, the incumbent industry hopes to artificially reproduce the lack of competition for TV distribution to which it is accustomed, based on geographical fiefdoms and turf."<ref name="ars-plottokill"/> The [[NCTA (association)|NCTA]] denied many of Free Press' arguments, stating that it was "an effort to ensure more content than ever is distributed over the Internet at no extra charge to consumers."<ref name="ars-plottokill"/>
In July 2014, BTIG analyst Richard Greenfield criticized the video on demand services offered through TV Everywhere systems for being ad-supported. In examples from [[FX (TV channel)|FX]] and [[TNT (U.S. TV network)|TNT]], he noticed that ads often repeated, and that in TNT's case, its version of an episode of ''[[The Last Ship (TV series)|The Last Ship]]'' included 20 minutes of unskippable ads across 45 minutes of programming. In conclusion, he contended that viewers would rather wait for programs to appear on subscription streaming services rather than use TV Everywhere services.<ref name="deadline-ads">{{cite web | url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/07/tv-everywhere-ads-repeat-video/ | title=What's The Problem With TV Everywhere? Take A Look: Video | publisher=Penske Media Corporation | work=Deadline Hollywood | date=July 2, 2014 | accessdate=July 10, 2014 | author=Lieberman, David}}</ref><ref name="nyp-adladen">{{cite web | url=https://nypost.com/2014/07/09/media-analyst-trashes-unfriendly-ad-laden-streaming/ | title=Media analyst trashes 'unfriendly' ad-laden streaming | work=New York Post | date=July 9, 2014 | accessdate=July 10, 2014 | author=Morgan, Richard}}</ref>
=== Viewer awareness === [[File:TV Everywhere generic logo.svg|thumb|right|180px|The Cable & Telecommunications Association for Marketing introduced a logo ''(pictured)'' intended for marketing TV Everywhere services.]] Despite efforts by broadcasters to educate viewers on TV Everywhere services and how to utilize them (including Fox, which produced a promotional video starring [[Jane Lynch]] as her ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]'' character [[Sue Sylvester]], describing the process as being less painful than [[waterboarding]]),<ref name=atd-foxwaterboarding/> critics and end-users criticized the registration and authentication processes for being frustrating and difficult. In response, providers took steps to improve their user experiences; [[Disney]] reported that use of its TV Everywhere services increased after it simply changed its process to use the term "verify" instead of "authenticate", [[Comcast]] and [[Cablevision]] introduced systems that automatically verify users with their [[residential gateway]]s, and Synacor (a provider of authentication platforms used by providers) added the ability for users to link their provider account to a [[Social networking service|social network]] [[OAuth|login]], such as Facebook or Twitter.<ref name=mcn-watershed/><ref name="atd-foxwaterboarding">{{cite web | url=http://allthingsd.com/20110727/signing-up-for-foxs-new-web-tv-plan-isnt-as-hard-a-being-waterboarded/ | title=Using Fox's New Web TV Plan Isn't as Hard as Being Waterboarded | publisher=Dow Jones & Company | work=All Things Digital | date=July 27, 2011 | accessdate=January 2, 2014 | author=Kafka, Peter}}</ref><ref name="atd-synacorsocial">{{cite web | url=http://allthingsd.com/20120906/exclusive-synacor-to-offer-tv-everywhere-authentication-via-social-ids/ | title=Exclusive: Synacor to Offer TV Everywhere Authentication Via Social IDs | publisher=Dow Jones & Company | work=All Things Digital | date=September 6, 2012 | accessdate=January 2, 2014 | author=Swisher, Kara}}</ref><ref name="atd-nbcpainful">{{cite web | url=http://allthingsd.com/20120605/nbcs-olympic-web-video-plan-live-legal-and-painful/ | title=NBC's Olympic Web Video Plan: Live, Legal and "Painful" | publisher=Dow Jones & Company | work=All Things Digital | date=June 5, 2012 | accessdate=January 2, 2014 | author=Kafka, Peter}}</ref>
For the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] and [[2014 Winter Olympics]], NBC worked closer with providers to help educate users, and produced customized marketing materials and video tutorials featuring [[Carson Daly]] (2012) and [[Ryan Seacrest]] (2014) to help inform users. As an incentive, NBC also allowed authenticated users to enter a sweepstakes to win a trip to London (2012) or [[Rio de Janeiro]] (2014).<ref name="mcn-nbc1000sochi">{{cite web | url=http://multichannel.com/news/content/nbc-olympics-present-1000-live-stream-hours-sochi/356709 | title=NBC Olympics to Present 1,000 Live-Stream Hours from Sochi | publisher=NewBay Media | work=Multichannel News | date=December 16, 2013 | accessdate=January 2, 2014 | author=Reynolds, Mike}}</ref><ref name="mcn-medal">{{cite web | url=http://www.multichannel.com/mahttp://multichannel.com/news/marketing/nbcu-looks-medal-tv-everywhere-olympic-authentication/289449rketing/nbcu-looks-medal-tv-everywhere-olympic-authentication/139203 | title=NBCU Looks to Medal with TV Everywhere Olympic Authentication | publisher=NewBay Media | work=Multichannel News | date=July 16, 2012 | accessdate=January 2, 2014 | author=Reynolds, Mike}}</ref>
Still, with dissatisfaction with the system and the [[nbcfail|quality of NBC's overall coverage]], there was an increase in the use of [[virtual private network]] (VPN) services to access the more comprehensive online coverage of the Games being provided by broadcasters in Canada ([[CTV Olympics|CTV]] in London, [[Olympics on CBC|CBC]] in Sochi) and the United Kingdom ([[BBC Sport|BBC]]), which only used [[geoblocking]] and did not require TV Everywhere authentication.<ref name="gigaom-nbcvpn">{{cite web | url=http://gigaom.com/2012/08/09/olympics-nbc-authentication-vpn/ | title=Olympic winners: How NBC's authentication helped VPN providers | work=Gigaom | date=August 9, 2012 | accessdate=March 12, 2014 | author=Roettgers, Janko}}</ref><ref name="gandm-cbcvpn">{{cite web | url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/olympics/some-us-viewers-turn-to-cbc-amid-complaints-about-nbcs-olympic-coverage/article16790846/ | title=Some U.S. viewers turn to CBC amid complaints about NBC's Olympic coverage | work=The Globe and Mail | date=February 10, 2014 | accessdate=March 12, 2014 | author=Szklarski, Cassandra}}</ref>
In April 2014, the Cable & Telecommunications Association for Marketing (CTAM) unveiled an industry-wide initiative for marketing and educating subscribers about TV Everywhere services provided by broadcasters and providers; these efforts include a stylized "tv everywhere" logo which the organization intends providers to use as a unified brand to denote TV Everywhere services. The logo consists of interlocking rectangles, representing multiple "screens" (platforms) for viewing content. The association also provided design recommendations for TV Everywhere user experiences, aiming to alleviate the confusion that had been experienced by users during the authentication process.<ref name="mcn-ctamlogo">{{cite web | url=http://www.multichannel.com/news/cable-operators/getting-know-tv-everywhere/373810 | title=Getting to Know 'tv everywhere' | publisher=NewBay Media | work=Multichannel News | date=April 14, 2014 | accessdate=May 25, 2014 | author=Gibbons, Kent}}</ref><ref name="mcn-ctamtve">{{cite web | url=http://www.multichannel.com/cable-show-2014-ctam-hopes-demystify-tv-everywhere/374300 | title=Cable Show 2014: CTAM Hopes to Demystify TV Everywhere | publisher=NewBay Media | work=Multichannel News | date=May 1, 2014 | accessdate=May 25, 2014 | author=Walsten, Jessika}}</ref>
=== Adoption === In a December 2013 survey of 4,205 pay television subscribers, [[NPD Group]] found that 21% of them used a TV Everywhere service at least once per month, and that 90% of them were satisfied with the experience. NPD analyst Russ Crupnick felt that "aggressive" use of the model was helping to counter cord cutting, which "speaks to the level of engagement they have with programming and a comfort in using the Internet to both access and interact with that programming."<ref name="mcn-npdsurvey"/> The study also found that 3 out of 10 pay television subscribers who were also subscribed to an SVOD service used TV Everywhere services at least once a week (in comparison to 2 out of 10 for those who were not).<ref name="mcn-npdsurvey">{{cite web | url=http://www.multichannel.com/news/tv-everywhere/study-21-pay-tv-subs-use-tv-everywhere-monthly/374386 | title=Study: 21% Of Pay-TV Subs Use TV Everywhere Monthly | publisher=NewBay Media | work=Multichannel News | date=May 6, 2014 | accessdate=May 25, 2014 | author=Baumgartner, Jeff}}</ref>
Amid criticism of NBC's coverage, adoption of NBC's TV Everywhere services during the 2014 Winter Olympics was still significantly large: on February 21, 2014, coverage of the [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's tournament#Semifinals|Men's hockey semi-final featuring the U.S. and Canada]] recorded the largest Live Extra audience in NBC Sports history, with 2.12 million unique viewers, augmenting the average [[NBCSN]] television audience of 3.9 million.<ref name="mcn-menshockeyrecord">{{cite web | url=http://multichannel.com/news/content/us-canada-men-s-hockey-semifinal-sets-streaming-record-nbc-sports-digital/356118 | title=U.S.–Canada Men's Hockey Semifinal Sets Streaming Record For NBC Sports Digital | publisher=NewBay Media | work=Multichannel News | date=February 21, 2014 | accessdate=March 12, 2014 | author=Baumgartner, Jeff}}</ref><ref name="mcn-nbcsnratings">{{cite web | url=http://multichannel.com/news/content/winter-olympics-nbcsn-scores-highest-rated-hockey-game-ever-canada-us-semifinal/356112 | title=Winter Olympics: NBCSN Scores Highest-Rated Hockey Game Ever with Canada-U.S. Semifinal | publisher=NewBay Media | work=Multichannel News | date=February 22, 2014 | accessdate=March 12, 2014 | author=Reynolds, Mike}}</ref> ESPN's coverage of the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] drew similarly heavy online viewership: during a group stage match between the U.S. and Portugal, at least 1.7 million concurrent viewers were using WatchESPN (though, not all of the viewers were necessarily watching the game).<ref name="engadget-17millionespn">{{cite web | url=https://www.engadget.com/2014/06/26/watchespn-brings-in-1-7-million-concurrent-viewers-for-usa-vs-germany/ | title=1.7 million people were using WatchESPN during the U.S. vs. Germany World Cup match | publisher=AOL Inc. | work=Engadget | date=June 26, 2014 | accessdate=June 27, 2014 | author=Wollman, Dana}}</ref>
In December 2015, research firm [[GfK]] estimated that 53% of the United States' pay television subscribers have used a TV Everywhere service—an increase from 42% in 2012, that overall use had doubled since 2012, and 79% of those surveyed found the login process easy. However, only 25% of those surveyed were aware of the term "TV Everywhere" or the CTAM logo, leading to the firm believing that consumer awareness and education was still a "critical missing piece" in the adoption of these services.<ref name=bc-awarenesschallenge>{{cite web|title=TV Everywhere Unknown But Being Used More|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/currency/tv-everywhere-unknown-being-used-more/146453|website=Broadcasting & Cable|publisher=NewBay Media|accessdate=22 December 2015}}</ref>
=== Platform non-neutrality === In 2014, [[Comcast]] was criticized for its decision to arbitrarily block access to [[HBO Go]] on [[PlayStation]] and [[Roku]] devices, but still allowing its use on competing [[Apple TV]] and [[Xbox 360]]. Comcast similarly blocked access to [[Showtime Anytime]] on Roku as well. A spokesperson for the provider stated that "with every new website, device or player we authenticate, we need to work through technical integration and customer service which takes time and resources. Moving forward, we will continue to prioritize as we partner with various players."<ref name=verge-comcasthbogo/>
During both the FCC's [[net neutrality]] hearings and comments regarding Comcast's then-proposed merger with [[Time Warner Cable]] (which, by contrast, allows HBO Go access on all supported devices), Roku criticized the provider for contradicting the TV Everywhere concept by discriminating against specific devices, thus prioritizing its own on-demand platform over external services. The company argued that providers could selectively favor certain platforms over others, further stating that "a large and powerful [[Multichannel video programming distributor|MVPD]] may use this leverage in negotiations with content providers or operators of streaming platforms, ultimately favoring parties that can either afford to pay for the privilege of authentication, or have other business leverage that can be used as a counterweight to discriminatory authentication."<ref name=verge-comcasthbogo>{{cite web|title=Comcast isn't letting customers watch HBO Go on PlayStation 3|url=https://www.theverge.com/2014/3/5/5474850/comcast-isnt-letting-customers-watch-hbo-go-on-ps3|website=The Verge|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=17 December 2014}}</ref><ref name=ars-hbogocomcast/>
On December 15, 2014, Comcast enabled the ability to use HBO Go and Showtime Anytime on Roku devices.<ref name=ars-hbogocomcast>{{cite web|title=Comcast to stop blocking HBO Go and Showtime on Roku streaming devices|url=https://arstechnica.com/business/2014/12/comcast-to-stop-blocking-hbo-go-and-showtime-on-roku-streaming-devices/|website=Ars Technica|publisher=Condé Nast Digital|accessdate=17 December 2014}}</ref> However, Comcast still blocked HBO Go on PlayStation consoles until December 2016.<ref name=verge-comcast-hbogo-ps4>{{cite web|title=Surprise: Comcast won't let anyone watch HBO Go on PlayStation 4|url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/3/5/8156025/comcast-blocks-hbo-go-sony-ps4|website=The Verge|accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.engadget.com/2016/12/07/comcast-finally-allows-hbo-espn-streaming-via-playstation-4/|title=Comcast finally allows HBO, ESPN streaming via PlayStation 4|work=Engadget|access-date=2017-12-20|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Password sharing === There have been instances of users deliberately sharing their TV Everywhere login credentials, or having them sold without their owner's knowledge on the [[black market]], in order to allow others to view programs without subscribing to the channel. [[Charter Communications]] CEO Tom Rutledge, and ESPN's executive vice president for affiliate sales and marketing Justin Connolly, have considered this practice equivalent to [[pirate decryption|piracy]]. In December 2017, it was reported that television providers and program distributors have begun to implement measures in order to discourage this practice, including reducing the length of login session, reducing the number of concurrent streams allowed on a single account, and monitoring unusual usage patterns such as large numbers of concurrent streams on a single account—especially those originating from outside of the customer's region, or during major programs.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-12-20/cable-tv-s-password-sharing-crackdown-is-coming|title=Cable TV’s Password-Sharing Crackdown Is Coming|date=2017-12-20|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-12-20}}</ref>

{{More footnotes|date=September 2017}} Under the provisions of the [[United Kingdom]] [[Housing Act 2004]] every [[landlord]] or [[letting agent]] that takes a [[tenancy deposit|deposit]] for an [[assured shorthold tenancy]] in [[England and Wales]] must protect the deposit under an authorised '''tenancy deposit scheme'''. The regulations came into effect on 6 April 2007, and were amended by the [[Localism Act 2011]], taking effect from 6 April 2012. The [[Deregulation Act 2015]] further amended the regulations from 26 March 2015.
==Reasons for introduction== It is common for landlords to take a dilapidation deposit from a tenant at the start of the tenancy. The deposit acts as a safeguard should the tenant cause any damage to the property. Some unscrupulous landlords are either very slow to return deposits at the end of the tenancy or make unfair deductions. The purpose of the regulations is to ensure good practice in this area, and try to keep disputes between landlords and tenants out of the courts by encouraging [[alternative dispute resolution]].
==Description== The tenant pays over the deposit (commonly one month's rent) in the usual way when the tenancy agreement is signed. The landlord or letting agency has 30 days from receipt of the deposit to provide the tenant with details of the scheme that they are using (known as the prescribed information). If there is no dispute at the end of the tenancy the deposit will be returned to the two parties as agreed. If a dispute has arisen then the parties will be invited to make use of the alternative dispute resolution process that is provided free within the scheme. Should the parties opt for alternative dispute resolution they will be bound by its decision with no redress to the courts.
There are two types of protection scheme:
– Custodial-based
– Insurance-based
The Custodial-based scheme is provided by the Deposit Protection Tenancy. It is free to use and the landlord or letting agents can simply pay the deposit online or over the phone. The money is held in a bank account by the Deposit Protection Scheme and transferred directly to the tenant once both parties agree on the total sum of money to release. Landlords based overseas must use the custodial Deposit Protection Service scheme unless they employ a British-registered letting agent to manage the tenancy.
When the deposit is under an insurance-based scheme, the Landlord or the letting agent will hold the deposit, but have to pay a fee to ensure the landlord will not illegally hold the deposit at the end of the tenancy. If at the end of the tenancy the landlord does not release the deposit, the insurance will pay back the tenant. This scheme is provided by deposits or the Tenancy Deposit Scheme.
==Schemes== {{As of|2016|November}} three companies are authorised by the UK government to run tenancy deposit schemes:<ref>{{cite web|title=Tenancy deposit protection|url=https://www.gov.uk/tenancy-deposit-protection/overview|website=gov.uk|accessdate=11 November 2016}}</ref>
*[https://www.tenancydepositscheme.com/ The Tenancy Deposit Scheme (TDS)] *MyDeposits *The Deposit Protection Service (The DPS)
TDS was the original tenancy deposit scheme - established in 2003 which many agents and landlords volunteered to use prior to the introduction of the legislation. Initially, the DPS offered only a custodial scheme while the TDS and MyDeposits offered only an insurance-backed scheme. From April 2013, the DPS also offered an insurance-backed scheme, and from April 2016, the TDS and MyDeposits both started offering a custodial scheme. Between April and September 2013, [[Capita]] also operated an insurance-backed scheme. Deposit protected by Capita was subsequently transferred to MyDeposits.
==Enforcement== If a landlord or letting agent does not both protect a tenant’s deposit and provide the tenant with the prescribed information within 30 days then they are prevented from regaining possession of the property under a Section 21 notice under the Housing Act 1988, unless the deposit is first repaid or proceedings for a penalty against the landlord, or its agent, has been initiated and settled.
If the tenant applies to court for the deposit to be protected and it is shown the landlord is not compliant with the scheme, then the court must order the landlord to pay the tenant between one and three times the deposit amount within 14 days.
Non-protection of a deposit taken before the commencement of the regulations on 6 April 2007 does not result in a penalty, but no valid Section 21 notice may be served until the deposit has been protected.
===Pre-2012 cases=== * Tiensia v Vision Enterprises Ltd<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWCA/Civ/2010/1224.html | title = Tiensia v Vision Enterprises Ltd (t/a Universal Estates) <nowiki>[2010]</nowiki> EWCA Civ 1224 }}</ref> - deposit registered after 14-day deadline * Gladehurst Properties Ltd v Hashemi - deposit never registered during tenancy * Draycott v Hannels - deposit registered after 14-day deadline * Harvey v Bamforth - deposit registered within 14 days but information not provided
The defences in these cases are affected by the [[Localism Act 2011]], which made the following changes to the law affecting deposit registration:<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2011/20/notes/division/5/7/6/4 | title = Section 184: Tenancy deposit schemes, Explanatory notes}}</ref> * Deadline for registration and providing prescribed information changed from 14 to 30 days following payment of the deposit * Penalties for non-compliance apply even if the registration is done late * Grants the court discretion to award 1x to 3x the deposit amount as a sanction, instead of 3x in all cases * The penalties for non-compliance apply even once the tenancy has ended
==Claims process== Either a Landlord or a tenant may begin the claims process from 14 days after the end of the tenancy.<ref name="DPS">[https://www.depositprotection.com/help/browse/agent-landlord/agent-single-claim-process Deposit Protection Service ] Retrieved October 2011</ref> The first step in beginning a claim is to obtain a so-called Statutory Declaration by accessing the Landlord or tenant's online account, and starting the process using an online form.<ref name="DPS"/> Once a claim has begun, the dispute service in question makes contact with both parties notifying them of the dispute, and requesting any additional evidence, before the claim is referred to an [[alternative dispute resolution]] service, unless either party states that they do not wish to use the ADR service or notifies in writing that they wish to resolve the dispute in the [[county court]]s, or alternatively another dispute resolution service.<ref name="DPS"/>
==Localism Act 2011== The Housing Act left open a loophole for landlords and letting agents. Although there was a penalty for not protecting the deposit or issuing prescribed information, there was no penalty for not doing so within the original 14 day limit. To close this loophole, the Localism Act 2011 extended the time limit for protecting tenancy deposits from 14 to 30 days, and this limit became absolute. Therefore, on the 31st day after the payment of the deposit money to the landlord the tenant can make an application to the court if the money has not been protected and the prescribed information given. Even if the deposit is registered or the prescribed information is given at any time after the 30-day window the tenant still has a right to make a claim. The claim will be for the return of the full sum of the deposit along with a penalty of between one and three times the sum of the deposit, to be awarded at the discretion of the Court. Tenants can also now make an application to a county court for a penalty award after the tenancy has ended.<ref>The Tenancy Deposit Scheme http://www.tds.gb.com/resources/files/The%20Housing%20Act%202004%20and%20the%20changes%20introduced%20by%20the%20Localism%20Act%202011.pdf</ref>
==Alternatives== There are a number of “no deposit” or “zero deposit” schemes in operation that are provided by insurance companies. These can offer landlords protection without having to take a deposit.
[[Bond scheme (housing)|Bond schemes]] are an alternative for those unable to afford a deposit. They are commonly used as a homelessness prevention measure.
==See also== * [[Rent control in England and Wales]]

{{Infobox legislation |short_title = Ukraine Citizenship Act |legislature = [[Parliament of Ukraine]] |image = Lesser Coat of Arms of Ukraine.svg |imagesize = |imagealt = |caption = |long_title = An Act relating to Ukrainian citizenship |citation = |territorial_extent = |enacted_by = [[Government of Ukraine]] |date_enacted = |date_passed = |enacted_by2 = |date_enacted2 = |date_passed2 = |date_assented = |royal_assent = |date_signed = |signed_by = |date_commenced = |date_of_expiry = |date_repealed = |administered_by = |bill = |bill_citation = |bill_date = |introduced_by = |1st_reading = |2nd_reading = |3rd_reading = |conf_committee_passed = |committee_report = |bill2 = |bill_citation2 = |bill_date2 = |introduced_by2 = |1st_reading2 = |2nd_reading2 = |3rd_reading2 = |conf_committee_passed2 = |committee_report2 = |date_conf_committee = |white_paper = |amendments = |repeals = |related_legislation = |summary = |keywords = |status = current }}
'''Ukrainian nationality law''' is the law of [[Ukraine]] which concerns [[citizenship]]. The body of law is primarily regulated by the Law of Ukraine on Citizenship of Ukraine and certain provisions within the [[Constitution of Ukraine]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mfa.gov.ua/mfa/en/273.htm |title=Citizenship |accessdate=2008-04-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121012012209/http://www.mfa.gov.ua/mfa/en/273.htm |archivedate=October 12, 2012 |df= }}. ''Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Ukraine''.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mfa.gov.ua/mfa/en/publication/content/719.htm |title=Law on Citizenship of Ukraine |accessdate=2008-04-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121012010014/http://www.mfa.gov.ua/mfa/en/publication/content/719.htm |archivedate=October 12, 2012 |df= }}. ''Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Ukraine''.</ref> The current law was adopted by the [[Verkhovna Rada]] after the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 1990|election]] of 26 July 1990 together with the [[Declaration of State Sovereignty of Ukraine|Declaration of State Sovereignty]].<ref name="Ukraine proclaims sovereignty UW">[http://www.ukrweekly.com/old/archive/1990/299001.shtml Ukraine proclaims sovereignty], ''[[The Ukrainian Weekly]]'' (July 22, 1990)</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=C8C3xuqd6aMC&pg=PA21&dq=Declaration+of+State+Sovereignty+of+Ukraine+July&hl=nl&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjZkaSQ4sbLAhXIwBQKHVv-DFcQ6AEIMDAD#v=onepage&q=Declaration%20of%20State%20Sovereignty%20of%20Ukraine%20July&f=false How Ukraine Became a Market Economy and Democracy] by [[Anders Åslund]], [[Peterson Institute for International Economics]], 2009, {{ISBN|978-0-88132-427-3}} (page 21)</ref>
==Definition of Ukrainian citizenship== Citizens of Ukraine typically fall into at least one of the following categories: * Former citizens of the [[Soviet Union|Union of Soviet Socialist Republics]] who were permanently resident on the territory of the former [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] at the moment of the [[Declaration of Independence of Ukraine]] on August 24, 1991. * Stateless people, residing on the territory of Ukraine on November 13, 1991. * People who came to Ukraine with the intent of taking up permanent residence since 13 November 1991 and who had the endorsement "Citizen of Ukraine" inserted into their 1974-type [[passport of the USSR|Soviet passport]] by Ukrainian authorities, as well as the children of such persons who arrived in Ukraine together with their parents, provided that they had not attained their majority before their entry to Ukraine. * People who acquired Ukrainian citizenship in accordance with the laws of Ukraine and the international treaties of Ukraine.
==Acquisition of citizenship== [[File:Ukrainian passport 2017.jpg|right|thumb|upright|The front cover of a biometric Ukrainian passport.]] [[Image:Ukrainian_biometric_passport_data_page.jpg|thumb|200px|right|International travel biometric [[Ukrainian passport|passport]] details page]] Citizenship of Ukraine may be acquired in any one of the following ways:<ref name=usopm>{{cite book|url=http://www.opm.gov/EXTRA/INVESTIGATE/is-01.PDF|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030406210657/http://www.opm.gov/extra/investigate/IS-01.pdf|title=Citizenship Laws of the World|publisher=Office of Personnel Management, Investigations Service|location=Washington, D.C.|date=March 2001|accessdate=2013-12-14|archivedate=2003-04-06|ref=CITEREFOPM2001}}</ref>
*By descent: ** Being born to parents, at least one of whom is a citizen of Ukraine. ** Being born abroad to stateless parents, but legally residing in Ukraine, and having acquired no other nationality at birth. ** Being born in Ukraine to non-Ukrainian parents, but legally residing in Ukraine and having not acquired the nationality of either parent. ** Being born in Ukraine to parents, at least one of whom is a registered refugee under Ukrainian law, and having not acquired the nationality of either parent or only the nationality of the parent holding refugee status. ** Being born in Ukraine to unknown parents. *By registration: ** Being adopted as a child by citizens of Ukraine. ** Having no other citizenship and at least one parent or grandparent Ukrainian by birth. ** Having no other citizenship, under certain conditions listed in the Statute on Citizenship. *By naturalization: ** Having resided in Ukraine for at least five years, being able to function in the Ukrainian language, and being knowledgeable of the Ukrainian Constitution. The individual is required to voluntarily renounce any foreign citizenships they may hold.
Birth within the territory of Ukraine does not automatically confer citizenship.
==Loss of citizenship== From 2005 until mid-2017 87.376 people lost their Ukrainian citizenship.<ref name=Ulc31717/> 67.305 of them voluntarily renounced it, 19.738 lost it because of international agreements and 333 were involuntary deprived of their citizenship.<ref name=Ulc31717>{{uk icon}} [http://pda.pravda.com.ua/news/id_7150944/For 11 years citizenship was deprived of almost 90 thousand Ukrainians], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (July 31, 2017)</ref>
===Voluntary loss of citizenship=== According to Ukraine's nationality law, Ukrainian citizenship can be voluntarily renounced by Ukrainian citizens who have taken up permanent residence in a foreign country and who have acquired a foreign citizenship or have received confirmation that they will acquire a foreign citizenship upon successful renunciation of their Ukrainian citizenship. Citizenship can only be renounced in the presence of a Ukrainian consular official at a [[List of diplomatic missions of Ukraine|Ukrainian diplomatic mission]] and proof of the final/impending acquisition of foreign citizenship is required to do so.
===Automatic loss of citizenship=== Automatic loss of Ukrainian citizenship occurs in the event an adult Ukrainian citizen voluntarily acquires a foreign nationality or enters into the military or governmental service of a foreign power.
Ukrainian citizenship is not automatically lost in the following circumstances:
*Acquiring a foreign citizenship at birth by descent from a parent when Ukrainian citizenship is also acquired by descent. *Being adopted by foreign nationals when Ukrainian citizenship was originally acquired by descent from a biological parent. *Automatically acquiring citizenship of one's spouse upon marriage to a foreign national. *Automatically acquiring a foreign citizenship upon reaching the age of majority in accordance with the nationality law of a foreign country. In this case Ukrainian citizenship is retained providing that the individual had no formal (documented) knowledge of the automatic acquisition of the foreign citizenship.
The decision on termination of Ukrainian citizenship must be taken by the [[President of Ukraine]].<ref>Law on Citizenship. Article 22.</ref>
==Dual citizenship== Ukrainian law currently does not recognise [[dual citizenship]].<ref>[http://www.rada.gov.ua/const/conengl.htm Constitution of Ukraine: Article 4] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110521190059/http://www.rada.gov.ua/const/conengl.htm |date=2011-05-21 }}</ref> However, there are citizens of Ukraine who hold dual citizenship.<ref>{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/articles/4b1aa47e76eef/ З життя українських олігархів – вілла Коломойського на Женевському озері], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (March 10, 2009)</ref><ref name="ukremb">{{cite news|url=http://ria.ru/incidents/20110907/431989797.html|script-title=ru:Посольство Украины подтвердило гибель трех украинцев в крушении Як-42|date=7 September 2011|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|accessdate=|location=Moscow|language=ru}}</ref> Ukrainian law states that (after gaining Ukrainian citizenship) the new Ukrainian citizen must renounce its non-Ukrainian citizenship(s) within two years.<ref>[http://www.rferl.mobi/a/georgia-saakashvili-citzenship-stripped/27406996.html Saakashvili Slams Georgian Decision To Revoke His Citizenship], [[Radio Free Europe]] (4 December 2015)</ref> A 2009 estimate put the number of Ukrainians with more than one passport from 300,000 to a few million.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/45040/ Dual Identities], [[Kyiv Post]] (July 9, 2009)</ref> Within Ukrainian boundaries Ukrainian citizens who also hold multiple citizenships are considered to be solely Ukrainian citizens.<ref>[http://www.mfa.gov.ua/mfa/en/publication/content/719.htm The Law of Ukraine On Citizenship of Ukraine: Article 2] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081204201403/http://www.mfa.gov.ua/mfa/en/publication/content/719.htm |date=2008-12-04 }}</ref> {{cquote|''If a citizen of Ukraine acquires citizenship (nationality) of another state or states, in legal relations with Ukraine, the person is recognized as a citizen of Ukraine only. If a foreigner acquires the citizenship of Ukraine, then in legal relations with Ukraine, the person is recognized as a citizen of Ukraine only...''| 20px|20px|''Article 2. Law on citizenship of Ukraine.''}}
On February 8, 2014, the Verkhovna Rada proposed a bill to criminalize the act of holding two citizenships.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.liga.net/news/politics/976681-v_radu_vnesen_zakonoproekt_nakazyvayushchiy_za_dvoynoe_grazhdanstvo.htm|title=В Раду внесен законопроект, наказывающий за двойное гражданство|author=|date=|website=liga.net|accessdate=21 April 2018}}</ref>
==Visa requirements== {{main|Visa requirements for Ukrainian citizens}} [[File:Visa requirements for Ukrainian citizens.png|thumbnail|400px|right|Visa requirements for Ukrainian citizens]]
In June 2017, Ukrainian citizens had visa-free or visa on arrival access to 116 countries and territories, ranking the Ukrainian passport 42nd in the world according to the Visa Restrictions Index.

revision.text:
'''[[Whistleblower]] protection in [[Australia]]''' is offered for certain disclosures under a patchwork of laws at both federal and state level. Eligibility for protection depends on the requirements of the applicable law and the subject matter of the disclosure. Not all disclosures are protected by law in Australia. At federal level, whistleblowers face potential imprisonment for making disclosures about certain subjects, including national security<ref name=farrelnatsec>{{cite news |title=Journalists and whistleblowers will go to jail under new national security laws |author=Paul Farrell |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/sep/26/journalists-and-whistleblowers-will-go-to-jail-under-new-national-security-laws |date=26 September 2014 |work=The Guardian}}</ref> and immigration<ref name=chilling>{{cite news |title=Border Force Act could see immigration detention centre workers jailed for whistleblowing |author=Sarah Sedghi |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-06-30/detention-centre-workers-face-imprisonment-for-whistleblowing/6584392 |date=1 July 2015 |work=ABC News |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation}}</ref> matters. [[Transparency International]] Australia considers the protections for private sector whistleblowers to be generally weaker than for those in the public sector, with the main provisions found in corporations legislation that does not mandate any internal company procedures.<ref name=tia>http://transparency.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/FINAL__-Whistleblower-Protection-Laws-in-G20-Countries-Priorities-for__-Action.pdf at page 24</ref>
Australia's first whistleblower protection laws were introduced in [[Queensland]] following the recommendations of the [[Fitzgerald Inquiry]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Dadic |first=Zac |title=Whistleblower Protection and Disclosures to Members of the Queensland Legislative Assembly |year=2009 |volume=24 |issue=2 |pages=97-113 |url=http://www.aspg.org.au/journal/2009spring_24_2/11-Dadic%20whistleblowings%20ANZACATT.pdf |publisher=Australasian Parliamentary Review}}</ref> Laws have subsequently been introduced in other states and territories, culminating with the adoption of federal legislation with the passage of the ''Public Interest Disclosure Act 2013''.
==Federal law==
===General provisions=== The ''Public Interest Disclosure Act 2013'' (PID Act) introduced a new comprehensive framework for protecting Commonwealth public sector whistleblowers.<ref name="pidabd">{{cite web |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/download/legislation/billsdgs/2494869/upload_binary/2494869.pdf;fileType=application%2Fpdf#search=%22legislation/billsdgs/2494869%22 |title=Bills Digest No. 125, 2012–13: Public Interest Disclosure Bill 2013 |accessdate=20 April 2016 |publisher=Australian Parliamentary Library}}</ref> The PID Act is the legislation underpinning the Commonwealth Government's Public Interest Disclosure (PID) Scheme to encourage public officials to report suspected wrongdoing in the Australian public sector. The PID Act arose in response to the report on Whistleblower Protection: a comprehensive scheme for the Commonwealth public sector by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.<ref> House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, Whistleblower Protection: a comprehensive scheme for the Commonwealth public sector, 2009 http://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/House_of_Representatives_Committees?url=laca/whistleblowing/report.htm </ref> During the Committee's Inquiry it was recognised that whistleblowers play an important role in ensuring accountability. As a result, those making disclosures needed to be protected from retribution.
The PID Act offers protection to 'whistleblowers' from reprisal action. The protection applies to public officials who disclose suspected illegal conduct, corruption, maladministration, abuses of public trust, deception relating to scientific research, wastage of public money, unreasonable danger to health or safety, danger to the environment or abuse of position or conduct which may be grounds for disciplinary action.
The Commonwealth Ombudsman has a significant role supporting and monitoring the administration of the whistleblower scheme established under the PID Act. The Commonwealth Ombudsman is responsible for promoting awareness and understanding of the PID Act as well as providing guidance, information and resources about making, managing and responding to disclosures.<ref>http://www.ombudsman.gov.au/about/making-a-disclosure</ref>
The unauthorised disclosure of Commonwealth information is a federal crime under section 70 of the ''Crimes Act 1914'' that carries a penalty of two years' imprisonment.<ref>{{Cite Legislation AU|Cth|act|ca191482|Crimes Act 1914|70}}</ref> The provision is often used to pursue whistleblowers and leaks by federal government employees and private contractors.<ref name=s70ref>{{cite news |title=Journalists reporting on asylum seekers referred to Australian police |author=Paul Farrell |url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2015/jan/22/journalists-reporting-on-asylum-seekers-referred-to-australian-police |date=22 January 2015 |work=The Guardian}}</ref> Since the [[Abbott Government]] took office, federal agencies have referred journalists from ''[[The Guardian]] Australia'', [[news.com.au]] and ''[[The West Australian]]'' using this provision in a bid to uncover the sources for immigration stories.<ref name="s70ref" />
===National security=== The ''National Security Amendment Act (No 1) 2014 (Cth)'' amended the legislation governing [[Australian Security Intelligence Organisation|ASIO]] to criminalise the disclosure of any information relating to a "Special Intelligence Operation".<ref name="natsecbd">{{cite web |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/download/legislation/billsdgs/3361366/upload_binary/3361366.pdf;fileType=application%2Fpdf#search=%22legislation/billsdgs/3361366%22 |title=Bills Digest No. 19, 2014-15: National Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2014 |date=3 June 2013 |accessdate=20 April 2016 |publisher=Australian Parliamentary Library}}</ref> ''The Guardian'' noted that any act committed by ASIO could be declaration a Special Intelligence Operation with the Attorney-General's approval and removed from scrutiny.<ref name=farrelnatsec />
===Immigration law=== Section 42 of the ''Australian Border Force Act 2015'' (Cth) imposes a penalty of two years' imprisonment for a whistleblower who makes a disclosure in relation to an [[Australian immigration detention facilities|Australian immigration detention facility]], although section 42(2)(c) exempts a disclosure where it is "required or authorised by or under a law of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory".<ref>{{Cite Legislation AU|Cth|act|abfa2015225|Australian Border Force Act 2015|42}}</ref>
[[The Conversation (website)|The Conversation]] considered whether the section 42(2)(c) exemption would apply so that a whistleblower could rely on the protections of ''Public Interest Disclosure Act 2013'' (Cth).<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://theconversation.com/factcheck-could-a-whistleblower-go-public-without-fear-of-prosecution-under-the-border-force-act-44467|title=FactCheck: Could a whistleblower go public without fear of prosecution under the Border Force Act?|last=Hoang|first=Khanh|website=The Conversation|access-date=2016-05-06}}</ref> It found that the exemption might indeed apply, but would do so subject to several qualifications, such as:<ref name=":0" /> * the whistleblower would first need to report their concerns internally * an external disclosure could only then be made after the whistleblower believed on reasonable grounds that the either the investigation or response were inadequate or delayed * the disclosure must not be contrary to the public interest nor make public sensitive information about law enforcement * the disclosure cannot be made about a matter in which a Minister has taken action or proposes to take action. Section 42 of the ''Australian Border Force Act 2015'' (Cth) has been criticised by the Australian Lawyers Alliance for its potential [[chilling effect]] on whistleblowers and journalists.<ref name="chilling" />
Medical professionals who have worked at [[Nauru]] are launching a [[High Court of Australia|High Court]] challenge against the secrecy provisions of the ''Australian Border Force Act 2015''.<ref>{{cite news|title=What are the secrecy provisions of the Border Force Act?|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-07-27/what-are-the-secrecy-provisions-of-the-border-force-act/7663608|accessdate=27 July 2016|work=ABC News|date=27 July 2016|language=en-AU}}</ref>
===Private sector=== [[Transparency International]] Australia considers the protections for private sector whistleblowers to be weaker than for those in the public sector, with the main provisions found in corporations legislation that does not mandate any internal company procedures.<ref name=tia />
Part 9.4AAA of the Corporations Act provides a degree of protection.<ref name="km">{{cite web |url=http://www.kordamentha.com/docs/default-source/for-publications/issue-14-05-protection-for-whistleblowers-in-australia.pdf2 |title= Blowing the whistle: Protection for whistleblowers in Australia |date=September 2014 |page=4 |accessdate=20 April 2016 |publisher=KordaMentha}}</ref>
==State and territory laws== Apart from South Australia, the [[States and territories of Australia|state and territory]] whistleblower protection laws only cover the public sector.<ref name=cpaa>{{cite web |url=http://www.cpaaustralia.com.au/~/media/corporate/allfiles/document/professional-resources/ethics/whistleblowing.pdf |title=Whistleblowing: Some Relevant Considerations |publisher=CPA Australia |page=9 |accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref> ===Queensland=== Protection is currently offered by the ''Public Interest Disclosure Act 2010'' (Qld).<ref name=bffs>{{cite web |url=https://blueprintforfreespeech.net/document/australia-overview |title=Australia – Whistleblowing Protection, Overview |date=20 November 2014 |publisher=Blueprint for Free Speech |accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref>
===New South Wales=== Protection is currently offered by the ''Protected Disclosures Act 1994'' (NSW).<ref name=bffs />
===Australian Capital Territory=== Protection is currently offered by the ''Public Interest Disclosure Act 2012'' (ACT).<ref name=bffs />
===Victoria=== Protection is currently offered by the ''Whistleblowers Protection Act 2001'' (Vic).<ref name=bffs />
===Tasmania=== Protection is currently offered by the ''Public Interest Disclosures Act 2002'' (Tas).<ref name=bffs />
===South Australia=== Protection is currently offered by the ''Whistleblowers Protection Act 1993'' (SA).<ref name=bffs />
===Western Australia=== Protection is currently offered by the ''Public Interest Disclosure Act 2003'' (WA).<ref name=bffs />
===Northern Territory=== Protection is currently offered by the ''Public Interest Disclosure Act 2008'' (NT).<ref name=cpaa />
==See also== *[[Whistleblowers Australia]]
